awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jennifer Crodelle is "A mathematical model for the role of gap junctions in the visual cortex." The host institution for the fellowship is Courant Institute, New York University, and the sponsoring scientist is David McLaughlin.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF mathematical sciences postdoctoral research fellowship afforded me the flexibility to pursue a new research direction, increase my network of collaborators and mentors, attend a variety of neuroscience courses, as well as increase my teaching portfolio. 

My main research project focused on understanding how a particular connection between neurons in the brain during development leads to observed neuron behavior in adults. Specifically, neurons in the primary visual cortex, the area of the brain responsible for interpreting visual input, respond preferentially to a particular orientation of a visual stimulus, called its orientation preference. This property forms very early in development. I sought to understand how gap junctions, or electrical connections among neurons, might affect the synaptic plasticity that occurs during development, ultimately leading to the formation of the orientation preference of the neurons. To investigate this question, I developed a mathematical model of the electrical activity of developing neurons and the plasticity, or modulation, of their synaptic connections. 

Our model results show that the inclusion of gap-junction coupling among pyramidal cells during development plays a significant role in determining a cell's orientation preference. As gap-junction coupling is often ignored in the modeling of neuronal networks during development, this work helps draw attention to its effects. It encourages future studies to include them in their models. 

These results are presented in a peer-reviewed journal article. As a result of collaborations with researchers at NYU, I published two other peer-reviewed journal articles, one on epidemiology and modeling the transmission of fear and the other on a mathematical model of damaged nerve cells and the resulting pain processing in the spinal cord. 

Through this grant, I had the opportunity to be part of the NYU community. As a result, I served as a research mentor to two women undergraduate students who presented their research project results at a national math conference, a first for both of them. I also reached out to the broader community of NYC by participating in an NYU mentorship outreach program, where we went to 4th- and 5th-grade classrooms and engaged students in science and math. I gave local high school students an interactive lecture to raise excitement and awareness of applied math and mathematical modeling. I disseminated my research and formed collaborations by attending and presenting at six academic/professional conferences, three different school seminars, and two workshops. 

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2021
Modified by: Jennifer Crodelle
